diagrams.description: Hydraulic engineering has ancient roots with early civilizations (3000 BCE onwards) developing irrigation systems in Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley, alongside Roman aqueducts demonstrating advanced water transport. The Middle Ages saw canal systems and watermills proliferate across Europe and Asia. The 18th century brought scientific foundations with Daniel Bernoulli's fluid dynamics principles (1738) and Antoine Ch√©zy's open channel flow equation (1768). The 19th century witnessed major canal projects, the development of turbines, and Manning's formula (1889) for channel flow. The early 1900s introduced major dam construction (Hoover Dam 1936) and hydroelectric power expansion. The 1950s-60s saw large-scale water projects worldwide and computer modeling emergence. The 1970s-80s advanced with numerical methods, pump technology improvements, and environmental considerations. The 1990s-2000s brought sophisticated hydraulic modeling software (HEC-RAS, CFD) and integrated water resources management. The 2010s-2020s continue with smart water systems, real-time monitoring, climate adaptation strategies, and sustainable hydraulic design becoming standard practice.

timeline
    title The History of Hydraulic Engineering
    section Ancient World
        6th Millennium BC : Irrigation in Mesopotamia and Egypt
        c. 300 BC : Archimedes - Screw pump and principles of hydrostatics
        Roman Empire : Aqueducts, dams, and public water supply systems
    section 17th-18th Centuries: Scientific Foundations
        1648 : Blaise Pascal - Pascal's Law (hydrostatics)
        1738 : Daniel Bernoulli - Bernoulli's principle (hydrodynamics)
        1795 : Joseph Bramah - The hydraulic press
    section 19th Century: Industrial Revolution
        1849 : James B. Francis - The Francis turbine
        1880s : Development of hydroelectric power
    section 20th Century: Large-Scale Projects
        1936 : Hoover Dam is completed
        1953 : The Delta Works in the Netherlands begins
        1960s : Development of computational fluid dynamics (CFD)
    section 21st Century
        2000s : Advancements in water resource management and environmental hydraulics
        2012 : Three Gorges Dam is completed
